Award.AwardTitle: International Conference on Representation Theory, Mathematical Physics and Integrable Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports the participation of US mathematicians in the conference Representation Theory, Mathematical Physics and Integrable Systems to be held June 4-8, 2018 at Centre International de Recontres Mathematiques in Luminy. Talks at the conference will address the latest progress in research at the nexus of representation theory, mathematical physics, and integrable systems, and will formulate open problems that will drive the development in these areas in the coming years. The conference will foster an environment for the establishment of lasting international collaborations between US and foreign researchers.

The conference will cover the latest developments on the interface of noncommutative algebra, differential and algebraic geometry, and perspectives arising from physics. These connections have proven numerous in recent decades, leading to advances like the development of new and powerful knot invariants, new perspectives on enumerative geometry and string theory, and the introduction of cluster algebra and categorification techniques into a broad range of subareas in algebra, geometry and mathematical physics. The conference website is https://conferences.cirm-math.fr/1746.html

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Outcomes related to Intellectual Merit:

The conferences featured talks by a number of leading mathematicians, who reported their latest research results on a wide range of topics in the areas of the conference: the Bethe ansatz for the diagonalization of quantum Hamitonians, categorification and representations of quantum groups, cluster algebras, fusion categories, Hamiltonian reductions of dynamical systems, invariants of 3-manifolds, asymptotic problems in statistical mechanics, Poisson Lie groups, random matrices and dimer models. The plenary lectures highlighted future directions and current trends in these rapidly developing areas. The speakers also discussed important open problems in the areas which stimulated a great deal of research after the conferences. The ample discussion time facilitated in depth collaboration and the exchange of ideas. Many research collaborations were formed after the conferences. The junior researchers had ample opportunities for personal discussions with the presenters from whom they learned a detailed picture of the latest research results in the areas.

Outcomes related to Broader Impacts:

The conference stimulated research collaborations between mathematicians working in the areas of Mathematical Physics and Integrable Systems. Due to the intense current research done in each of these areas, research collaborations across these areas will definitely have substantial impact on each of them. The conference also stimulated the international collaboration between US, EU and Asian mathematicians working in the above mentioned three areas.

More than a half of the participants at the conference were PhD students, postdocs and tenure-track assistant professors. The conference presented a unique opportunity for all of these groups of mathematicians to communicate their own research through lectures and posters. There were numerous research discussion between the junior and senior participants.

The conference proceedings will be published in the series Progress in Mathematics, thus making available the ideas of the  talks to a large audience of mathematicians.
 
Edward Frenkel gave an interview with French reporters for a general audience which is available on the website of CIRM. It has had a high impact on popularizing mathematics in society.

Summary of Outcomes:

The grant supported the participation of junior US mathematicians at the Conference on Theory, Mathematical Physics and Integrable Systems at the Mathematical Institute CIRM, Luminy during June 4–8, 2018. The areas of Representation Theory, Mathematical Physics and Integrable Systems are central areas of Mathematics which are the topic of intense current research. The conference offered a platform for communicating the latest research developments and for establishing new contacts between researchers working in the three areas of the conference. The conference also stimulated research collaborations between US mathematicians and those working in the EU and Asia.

The PIs made a great effort in attracting many female mathematicians and junior participants. Among the 26 talks of the conference, 10 were by junior US participants (PhD students, postdocs and assistant professors). There was a 2 hour poster session on the first day of the conference and posters were kept for the full duration of the conference for further discussions.

The Progress of Mathematics volume, the online availability of some of the talks of the conference and Frenkel's interview will be beneficial to the whole mathematics community and will have an impact on popularizing mathematics in society.
